sn48.49:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
sn48.49:1.3: Now at that time Venerable Bhāradvāja the Alms-Gatherer had declared enlightenment:
sn48.49:1.4: “I understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”
sn48.49:1.5: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. Then they said,
sn48.49:2.3: “What reason does Bhāradvāja the Alms-Gatherer see for doing this?”
sn48.49:3.1: “It’s because Bhāradvāja the Alms-Gatherer has developed and cultivated three faculties that he declares enlightenment:
sn48.49:3.2: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.”’
sn48.49:3.4: The faculties of mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.
sn48.49:3.5: It’s because Bhāradvāja the Alms-Gatherer has developed and cultivated these three faculties that he declares enlightenment.
sn48.49:3.7: What’s the culmination of these three faculties?
sn48.49:3.10: Of rebirth, old age, and death.
sn48.49:3.11: It’s because he sees that they culminate in the ending of rebirth, old age, and death that Bhāradvāja the Alms-Gatherer declares enlightenment:
sn48.49:3.12: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.”’”
